elements.content: A trinuclear complex [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)­(NO3)3]­·MeOH­·H2O (1) is synthesized by using a metalloligand [CuL] (H2L = N,N′-bis(salicylidene)-1,3-propanediamine or salpn). This complex is used as a new 3d-4f metallatecton for stepwise supramolecular oligomerization along with a simple diimine linker, 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy). A ratio of metallatecton/linker = 2:1 is conducive for the formation of a dimer [{(CuL)2Tb­(H2O)­(NO3)3}2bpy]­·2MeOH­·4H2O (2), whereas a higher proportion of linker at a ratio of 1:1 gives rise to a zigzag one-dimensional coordination polymer {[(CuL)2Tb­(NO3)3­bpy]­·MeOH­·2H2O}∞ (3). The inherent conformational flexibility of the trinuclear (CuL)2Tb node which is folded (cisoid) for 1 and 2 (asymmetric TbO9 tricapped trigonal prism) and unfolded (transoid) for 3 (a C 2-symmetric TbO10 tetradecahedron) seems to stabilize the crystal packing of these coordination-driven self-assemblies. The rapidly saturated magnetization at 1.8 K for 1 (11 μB) and 2 (22 μB) clearly indicates the presence of Tb–Cu ferromagnetic coupling through the phenoxido bridges of the Cu(μ1,1-O)2­Tb(μ1,1-O)2Cu cores. A slow saturation behavior has been found for 3 (9.5 μB). Both in-phase and out-of-phase ac magnetic measurements of 1 under an applied dc magnetic field reveal temperature dependence of the susceptibility at different frequencies below 5 K, characteristic of single molecule magnets (SMMs), which is conserved in 2 and 3 signifying oligo- and polymeric aggregates of SMMs.

elements.content: A trinuclear complex ([CuL]2Tb(H2O)­(NO3)3­·MeOH­·H2O) [H2L = salpn] were synthesized, characterized as a potential SMM below 5 K, and used as a new metallatecton. In combination with 1/2 and equimolar concentration of 4,4′-bipyridine, the metallatectons were stepwise assembled as a dimer and a one-dimensional coordination polymer that associated with conformational changes of the trinuclear node. However, these single molecule magnet (SMM)-aggregates retain SMM characteristics as its monomeric unit.

elements.content: The last two decades have been found to be extremely significant for structural chemists in two contexts that deserve special mention. First, the rational design of molecular architecture involves the engineering of multidimensional arrays, and networks containing metal ions as nodes have gained considerable advancement. On the other hand, the discovery of molecular clusters with strong uniaxial anisotropy behaving like nanosized magnets at low temperature, called single molecule magnets (SMMs), creates huge attention. Very recently, the common thread of supramolecular chemistry and molecular magnetism nurtured the strategy of self-assembly of SMMs as tailored building-blocks. These include controlled anchoring of SMMs onto the surface or networking within crystal, which can be possibly advantageous for information storage at the molecular level, quantum information processing, and molecular spintronics. The networking of SMM into n-dimensional (nD, n = 0, 1, 2, 3) arrays has been done by various strategies. A common approach is to use a well-characterized polymetallic (both homo- and heterometallic) SMM complex consisting of replaceable coligands or available coordination site as nodes and exodentate organic/inorganic ligands as “spacers” or “linkers” to link the SMMs. Both the nodes and the spacers dictate the dimensionality and structural integrity of the SMM-aggregate as well as their modification of intrinsic magnetic behavior. The modification arises from the extent of coupling of two or more SMMs, but the coupling must be very weak in order to maintain the intrinsic single-molecule properties of each SMM. Lanthanides came into this scenario about a decade ago. Systems comprising only the 4f-ion (low lying f orbital) in most cases hardly show any long-range exchange interaction with each other, whereas those of organic radicals (2p) or transition metals (3d) in combination with anisotropic lanthanides with large ground spin quantum number (S) have proved to be useful in this regard. Hence 3d-4f coordination clusters still remain significant to build nD-coordination networks using appropriate spacers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The last two decades have been found to be extremely significant for structural chemists in two contexts that deserve special mention. First, the rational design of molecular architecture involves the engineering of multidimensional arrays, and networks containing metal ions as nodes have gained considerable advancement. On the other hand, the discovery of molecular clusters with strong uniaxial anisotropy behaving like nanosized magnets at low temperature, called single molecule magnets (SMMs), creates huge attention. Very recently, the common thread of supramolecular chemistry and molecular magnetism nurtured the strategy of self-assembly of SMMs as tailored building-blocks. These include controlled anchoring of SMMs onto the surface or networking within crystal, which can be possibly advantageous for information storage at the molecular level, quantum information processing, and molecular spintronics. The networking of SMM into n-dimensional (nD, n = 0, 1, 2, 3) arrays has been done by various strategies. A common approach is to use a well-characterized polymetallic (both homo- and heterometallic) SMM complex consisting of replaceable coligands or available coordination site as nodes and exodentate organic/inorganic ligands as "spacers" or "linkers" to link the SMMs. Both the nodes and the spacers dictate the dimensionality and structural integrity of the SMM-aggregate as well as their modification of intrinsic magnetic behavior. The modification arises from the extent of coupling of two or more SMMs, but the coupling must be very weak in order to maintain the intrinsic single-molecule properties of each SMM. Lanthanides came into this scenario about a decade ago. Systems comprising only the 4f-ion (low lying f orbital) in most cases hardly show any long-range exchange interaction with each other, whereas those of organic radicals (2p) or transition metals (3d) in combination with anisotropic lanthanides with large ground spin quantum number (S) have proved to be useful in this regard. Hence 3d-4f coordination clusters still remain significant to build nD-coordination networks using appropriate spacers.

elements.content: A large number of current 3d-4f SMMs that have been employed for networking are mostly derived from compartmental N2O4 or macrocyclic oligo-N2O2 Schiff bases. However, neither the SMM properties of the [(ML)2M′X n ] (H2L is N2O2 salen-type Schiff base ligands, X is anionic coligands, M is 3d metal ion, and M′ is lanthanide (Ln) ion) have been explored, nor have they been used as nodes to construct polymeric complexes although such species are known since long. Recently, we have successfully employed the trinuclear [(ML)2M′X n ] complexes (where M = Cu(II) or Ni(II) and M′ = Co(II), Cd(II), or Zn(II)) as polymetallic nodes and have shown that their conformational flexibility (Scheme ) can induce structural diversity and isomerism which may even be associated with a drastic change in the magnetic behavior. The results encourage us to extend our venture in incorporating anisotropic Ln ions such as TbIII by the salen-type metalloligands and investigate their SMM properties. Moreover, we also intend to employ this oligonuclear species as molecular building blocks for nD networking.

Recently, we have successfully employed the trinuclear [(ML)2M'X n ] complexes (where M = Cu(II) or Ni(II) and M' = Co(II), Cd(II), or Zn(II)) as polymetallic nodes and have shown that their conformational flexibility (Scheme ) can induce structural diversity and isomerism which may even be associated with a drastic change in the magnetic behavior. elements.clean_text: 1  Linear-Bent Flexibility of (ML)2M' Coordination Cluster

elements.content: The idea of supramolecular linking of SMM clusters by a large variety of both inorganic and organic exodentate spacers gives rise to a great number of coordination polymers showing modified SMM or single chain magnet (SCM) properties. Metal-containing anionic dia- or para-magnetic spacers, e.g., cyanometalates, metalloligands have afforded huge success in this context. However, neutral ditopic di-imine spacers have had very limited access for linking oligonuclear 3d-4f nodes and no previous utilization in connecting 3d-4f SMM in the nD array (n > 0) despite being very iconic in crystal engineering. The simple di-imine such as 4,4′-bipyridyl (bpy) could be advantageous for this purpose as it is prone to ligate to the 3d center over the 4f center and is expected to transmit negligible inter-SMM exchange interaction, and consequently the dynamics of magnetization should remain almost identical to that of the isolated 3d-4f SMMs.
elements.clean_text: The idea of supramolecular linking of SMM clusters by a large variety of both inorganic and organic exodentate spacers gives rise to a great number of coordination polymers showing modified SMM or single chain magnet (SCM) properties. Metal-containing anionic dia- or para-magnetic spacers, e.g., cyanometalates, metalloligands have afforded huge success in this context. However, neutral ditopic di-imine spacers have had very limited access for linking oligonuclear 3d-4f nodes and no previous utilization in connecting 3d-4f SMM in the nD array (n > 0) despite being very iconic in crystal engineering. The simple di-imine such as 4,4'-bipyridyl (bpy) could be advantageous for this purpose as it is prone to ligate to the 3d center over the 4f center and is expected to transmit negligible inter-SMM exchange interaction, and consequently the dynamics of magnetization should remain almost identical to that of the isolated 3d-4f SMMs.

elements.content: Herein, we report synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of three structurally related Cu2Tb complexes. Complex 1 ([(CuL)2Tb­(H2O)(NO3)3]­·MeOH­·H2O) is synthesized by reacting metalloligand [CuL] (where H2L = N,N′-bis(salicylidene)-1,3-propanediamine or salpn) with Tb(NO3)3·5H2O, while complexes 2 ([{(CuL)2Tb­(H2O)­(NO3)3}2bpy]­·2MeOH­·4H2O) and 3 ({[(CuL)2Tb­(NO3)3bpy]­·MeOH­·2H2O} n ) are synthesized by reacting complex 1 with bpy in 2:1 and 1:1 ratios, respectively. Complex 2 is a dimeric self-assembly of 1 through bpy linker, whereas complex 3 represents a zigzag one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer where the (CuL)2Tb nodes are joined by bpy. The conformations of the trinuclear nodes are different: it is “bent” in 1 and 2 but “linear” in 3. The ac magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal slow relaxation of magnetization reorientation for all three complexes. It is worth mentioning that although a few other members of the family of (ML)2LnX3 complexes where H2L is the N2O2 salen-type Schiff base ligands are known and their magnetic coupling has been studied, complex 1 is the first member of this family that shows SMM behavior. Moreover, the utilization of stoichiometric variation of the di-imine spacer, bpy in the stepwise assembly of polymetallic nodes from dimeric to 1D polymeric aggregation, is very rare in molecular tectonics. The aggregation induces interesting variations in conformations of the trinuclear nodes as well as in the local environment around TbIII that provide a rare opportunity to study the dependence of SMM properties of the same core in different coordination environments.

Complex 2 is a dimeric self-assembly of 1 through bpy linker, whereas complex 3 represents a zigzag one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer where the (CuL)2Tb nodes are joined by bpy. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Starting Materials

Salicylaldehyde and 1,3-propanediamine were purchased from Lancaster and were reagent grade. They were used without further purification. Reagent grade Tb(NO3)3⋅5H2O and 4,4'-bipyridine were purchased from Aldrich.

elements.content:
Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.

Synthesis of the Schiff Base Ligand H<sub>2</sub>L and Ligand Complex [CuL]

The di-Schiff-base ligand H2L was prepared by a standard method. Five mmoles of 1,3- propanediamine (0.42 mL) was mixed with 10 mmol of salicylaldehyde (1.04 mL) in methanol (20 mL). The resulting solution was put under reflux for about 2 h and allowed to cool. The yellow-colored methanolic solution was used directly for complex formation. To a methanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol), a methanolic solution of H2L (5 mmol, 10 mL) and triethyl amine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was added to prepare the respective precursor “metalloligand” [CuL] as reported earlier.

Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care. 

Synthesis of the Schiff Base Ligand H2L and Ligand Complex [CuL]

The di-Schiff-base ligand H2L was prepared by a standard method. Five mmoles of 1,3- propanediamine (0.42 mL) was mixed with 10 mmol of salicylaldehyde (1.04 mL) in methanol (20 mL). The resulting solution was put under reflux for about 2 h and allowed to cool. The yellow-colored methanolic solution was used directly for complex formation. To a methanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol), a methanolic solution of H2L (5 mmol, 10 mL) and triethyl amine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was added to prepare the respective precursor "metalloligand" [CuL] as reported earlier.

elements.content: The “metalloligand” [CuL] (343.5 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol and to it a solution of Tb(NO3)3·5H2O (217.5 mg, 0.5 mmol in 5 mL of methanol) was added and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation at room temperature. After 3 days, well-shaped dark green X-ray quality single crystals deposited at the bottom of the vessel. They were collected washed with a little methanol and allowed to dry at open atmosphere.

Synthesis of Complex [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)(NO3)3]⋅MeOH⋅H2O (1)

The "metalloligand" [CuL] (343.5 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol and to it a solution of Tb(NO3)3⋅5H2O (217.5 mg, 0.5 mmol in 5 mL of methanol) was added and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation at room temperature. After 3 days, well-shaped dark green X-ray quality single crystals deposited at the bottom of the vessel. They were collected washed with a little methanol and allowed to dry at open atmosphere.

elements.content: All measurements were carried out on powdered samples of the respective polycrystalline compounds. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a Perkin Elmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. IR spectra in KBr pellets (4000–500 cm–1) were recorded using a Perkin Elmer RXI FT-IR spectrophotometer. Electronic spectra were recorded in spectroscopic grade methanol (800–250 nm) in a 1 cm optical glass cuvette as well as in solid state (800–300 nm) in a Hitachi U-3501 spectrophotometer using an appropriate set up. Thermal analyses (TG-DTA) were carried out on a Mettler Toledo Star TGA/SDTA 851 thermal analyzer in a dynamic atmosphere of N2 (flow rate 50 cm3 min–1). The samples were heated in an alumina crucible at a rate of 10 °C min–1 up to 350 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a RIGAKU Ultima III diffractometer using monochromated Cu Kα (α = 0.15406 nm) radiation at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

All measurements were carried out on powdered samples of the respective polycrystalline compounds. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a Perkin Elmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. IR spectra in KBr pellets (4000-500 cm-1) were recorded using a Perkin Elmer RXI FT-IR spectrophotometer. Electronic spectra were recorded in spectroscopic grade methanol (800-250 nm) in a 1 cm optical glass cuvette as well as in solid state (800-300 nm) in a Hitachi U-3501 spectrophotometer using an appropriate set up. Thermal analyses (TG-DTA) were carried out on a Mettler Toledo Star TGA/SDTA 851 thermal analyzer in a dynamic atmosphere of N2 (flow rate 50 cm3 min-1). The samples were heated in an alumina crucible at a rate of 10 °C min-1 up to 350 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a RIGAKU Ultima III diffractometer using monochromated Cu Kα (α = 0.15406 nm) radiation at room temperature.

elements.content: The dc magnetic susceptibilities and magnetization of polycrystalline specimens of 1, 2, and 3 were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T coil in a temperature range of 1.8–300 K. The magnetic responses were corrected with diamagnetic blank data of the sample holder measured separately. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample itself was estimated from Pascal’s constants. The ac magnetic susceptibilities of 1, 2, and 3 were recorded on a Quantum Design PPMS ac/dc magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

The dc magnetic susceptibilities and magnetization of polycrystalline specimens of 1, 2, and 3 were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T coil in a temperature range of 1.8-300 K. The magnetic responses were corrected with diamagnetic blank data of the sample holder measured separately. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample itself was estimated from Pascal's constants. The ac magnetic susceptibilities of 1, 2, and 3 were recorded on a Quantum Design PPMS ac/dc magnetometer.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of complexes 1, 2, and 3 were mounted on a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The crystals were placed at 60 mm from the CCD. A total of 360 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. The structures were solved using the Patterson method by using the SHELXS 97 program. Subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and least-squares refinement revealed the positions of the remaining non-hydrogen atoms. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with independent anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions, and their displacement parameters were fixed to be 1.2 times larger than those of the attached non-hydrogen atom, except for the hydrogen atoms of the disordered water molecules in the complexes which could not be located in Fourier map. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON 99, ORTEP-32, and WinGX system Ver-1.64. Data collection with selected structure refinement parameters and bond distances and bond angles for all the complexes are given in Table and Tables S1–S2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

Suitable single crystals of complexes 1, 2, and 3 were mounted on a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The crystals were placed at 60 mm from the CCD. A total of 360 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. The structures were solved using the Patterson method by using the SHELXS 97 program. Subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and least-squares refinement revealed the positions of the remaining non-hydrogen atoms. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with independent anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions, and their displacement parameters were fixed to be 1.2 times larger than those of the attached non-hydrogen atom, except for the hydrogen atoms of the disordered water molecules in the complexes which could not be located in Fourier map. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON 99, ORTEP-32, and WinGX system Ver-1.64. Data collection with selected structure refinement parameters and bond distances and bond angles for all the complexes are given in Table  and Tables S1-S2, respectively.

Recently we successfully synthesized several discrete and polymeric [(ML)2M′X n ] type complexes [where, M represent CuII and NiII and M′ are different s-, p-, d-, and 5f-block elements]. In these polymeric complexes, coordination cluster (ML)2M′ and the bridging anion X act as a node and a linker, respectively. In our present attempt, we incorporate Tb3+ ion with the help of “metalloligand” [CuL] to produce [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)­(NO3)3]­·MeOH­·H2O (1) as dark green crystals (Scheme ). We then join this cluster by a neutral di-imine linker bpy instead of an anionic linker which was used by us before. The advantage of using neutral bpy ligand is that we can control the node/linker ratio, which, in the case of anionic linkers, is fixed as the requirement for balancing charge. Taking this advantage we synthesize a dimer (complex 2) and a 1D-chain (complex 3) simply by reacting the (CuL)2Ln node (complex 1) and the bpy linker in 2:1 and 1:1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of the Complexes

Recently we successfully synthesized several discrete and polymeric [(ML)2M'X n ] type complexes [where, M represent CuII and NiII and M' are different s-, p-, d-, and 5f-block elements]. In these polymeric complexes, coordination cluster (ML)2M' and the bridging anion X act as a node and a linker, respectively. In our present attempt, we incorporate Tb3+ ion with the help of "metalloligand" [CuL] to produce [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)(NO3)3]⋅MeOH⋅H2O (1) as dark green crystals (Scheme ). We then join this cluster by a neutral di-imine linker bpy instead of an anionic linker which was used by us before. The advantage of using neutral bpy ligand is that we can control the node/linker ratio, which, in the case of anionic linkers, is fixed as the requirement for balancing charge. Taking this advantage we synthesize a dimer (complex 2) and a 1D-chain (complex 3) simply by reacting the (CuL)2Ln node (complex 1) and the bpy linker in 2:1 and 1:1, respectively.

elements.clean_text: 2  Syntheses of Complexes 1-3

elements.content: Besides elemental analyses, all the complexes were initially characterized by IR spectra. The precursor metalloligand [CuL] is neutral and does not have any counteranion, whereas all three complexes contain IR active nitrato coligands. The nitrato anion shows its characteristic bands for bidentate chelation in each compound. In all complexes, a strong and sharp band due to the azomethine ν(CN) group of the Schiff base appears at 1620–1626 cm–1 for [CuL] as observed before. All three complexes along with the free metalloligand [CuL] were characterized by UV–vis spectroscopy. In solutions, all of them show identical UV–vis spectra with the intense bands at ∼602, 360, and 274 nm, which are very close to those of free metalloligand (595, 360, and 274 nm) (, Figure S1). These bands are characterized as d–d transition, ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), and intraligand n−π* transition of the metalloligands, respectively. The LMCT bands of these type metalloligands on complexation exert a hypsochromic shift which is not observed in this case, signifying on sufficient dilution these complexes dissociated to its precursors. On the other hand, the solid state UV–VIS spectra of the complexes are quite different from the metalloligand. The d–d transition band of the metalloligand (598 nm) exhibits significant bathochromic shifts for complexes 1 (611 nm), 2 (617 nm), and 3 (614 nm) in agreement with the square pyramidal Cu(II) centers in the solid state structure. The phase purity of all the complexes is determined from identity of the PXRD pattern (, Figure S2). All three complexes show weight loss, in the temperature ranges of approximately 80–130 °C owing to the loss of methanol and water molecules, followed by the pyrolytic ligand degradation (, Figure S3).

elements.content: Both complexes 1 and 2 are crystallized in the triclinic crystal system and P1̅ space group. Detailed crystallographic parameters are given in Table . In the trinuclear molecule of [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)­(NO3)3]­·MeOH­·H2O (1), two neutral metalloligands are chelated to the central TbIII atom in an asymmetric angular orientation via two μ2-phenoxido oxygen atoms (Figure A). Two chelating nitrato (κ2O,O′) and one coordinated water molecule complete the nona-coordination of TbIII. The third nitrato ligand is coordinated axially to the CuII atom of one of the coordinated metalloligands to make its geometry square pyramidal. Complex 2 is formed by joining of two trinuclear Cu2Tb units through the coordination of a bpy molecule to one of the axial sites of the CuII center of each trinuclear unit. The molecule contains an inversion center that lies on the bpy ligand. The dimensions of the metal coordination environments () of the (CuL)2Tb node in 2 remain very similar to those in complex 1; the only difference lies in the coordination environment of one of the CuII, which is square planar in 1 but is square pyramidal in 2 (Figure B).
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Structures

Both complexes 1 and 2 are crystallized in the triclinic crystal system and P1̅ space group. Detailed crystallographic parameters are given in Table . In the trinuclear molecule of [(CuL)2Tb(H2O)(NO3)3]⋅MeOH⋅H2O (1), two neutral metalloligands are chelated to the central TbIII atom in an asymmetric angular orientation via two μ2-phenoxido oxygen atoms (Figure A). Two chelating nitrato (κ2O,O') and one coordinated water molecule complete the nona-coordination of TbIII. The third nitrato ligand is coordinated axially to the CuII atom of one of the coordinated metalloligands to make its geometry square pyramidal. Complex 2 is formed by joining of two trinuclear Cu2Tb units through the coordination of a bpy molecule to one of the axial sites of the CuII center of each trinuclear unit. The molecule contains an inversion center that lies on the bpy ligand. The dimensions of the metal coordination environments () of the (CuL)2Tb node in 2 remain very similar to those in complex 1; the only difference lies in the coordination environment of one of the CuII, which is square planar in 1 but is square pyramidal in 2 (Figure B).

elements.content: Molecular structure of complexes 1 (A) and 2 (B) along with a schematic diagram of TbIII coordination sphere (C) (H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity; color scheme Tb green, Cu cyan, O red, N blue, C gray; symmetry operation a = –x, −y, −z).
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of complexes 1 (A) and 2 (B) along with a schematic diagram of TbIII coordination sphere (C) (H atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity; color scheme Tb green, Cu cyan, O red, N blue, C gray; symmetry operation a = -x, -y, -z).

elements.content: The vertexes of the coordination polyhedron of the central TbIII ion in complex 1 and in asymmetric unit of complex 2 are constructed by nine oxygen atoms giving rise to a tricapped trigonal prism (Figure C) with average Tb–O bond distances of 2.443(15) and 2.447(17) Å, respectively. The four of the nine oxygen atoms namely O(1), O(2) and O(3), O(4) that belong to the two metalloligands are at distances 2.351(4)–2.501(5) Å and 2.368(5)–2.438(5) Å for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Another four oxygens belonging to two nitrato coligands, i.e., O(8), O(10) and O(11), O(13) are at distances between 2.462(6)–2.554(6) Å and 2.457(5)–2.586(5) Å for 1 and 2, respectively. The remaining one, O(14) from a water molecule, is at a distance of 2.348(5) Å and 2.363(6) Å for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The angle between the planes of the two triangular faces of the prism (O(1), O(3), O(4) and O(8), O(11), O(14)) is 11.5(2)° for 1 and 17.1(2)° for 2. The plane of the three capping atoms (O(2), O(10), and O(13)) is nearly parallel with the O(8)–O(11)–O(14) plane (1.4(2)° and 5.6(2)° for 1 and 2, respectively) but is rather inclined with the O(1)–O(3)–O(4) plane making an angle of 10.4(2)° for 1 and 15.5(2)° for 2. The distances between the centroids of the two triangular faces (Cg(1) and Cg(2)) are nearly equal (3.434(1) and 3.410(1) Å for 1 and 2, respectively). The Cg(1)–Tb(1)–Cg(2) angles deviate from the ideal value, i.e., 180° to 175.4(1)° in 1 and 173.9(1)° in 2. Thus, on dimerization, the distortion of the coordination sphere increases without any elongation or contraction along the z-direction. The chelating angles to the terbium center by the two metalloligands are at 67.26(15)°, 63.27(15)° and 66.24(17)°, 63.86(16)° whereas those of nitrato ligands are 50.66(25)° and 49.92(27)° (at an average) for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: Each of the two terminal copper atoms of the trinuclear (CuIIL)2TbIII core for complexes 1 and 2 is bonded to four donor atoms [O(1), O(2), N(1), N(2) for Cu(1) and O(3), O(4), N(3), N(4) for Cu(2)] of the tetradentate N2O2 ligand L2– making up a planar arrangement. The Cu–O and Cu–N distances are in the ranges 1.923(4)–1.968(4) and 1.938(8)–1.984(6) Å for complex 1 and 1.952(5)–1.980(5) and 1.965(7)–2.000(7) Å for complex 2. One of the axial coordination sites of Cu(1) atom is occupied by an oxygen atom O(5) of a nitrato coligand at a distance of 2.421(6) and 2.446(7) Å for 1 and 2, respectively, indicating a square-pyramidal geometry. On the contrary, Cu(2) has no axially coordinated ligand in complex 1, while in complex 2 one of its axial positions is coordinated by N(5) of the bpy spacer at a distance of 2.371(7) Å making a square-pyramidal environment. Around Cu(1) the r.m.s. deviations of the four basally coordinated atoms from the mean plane passing through them are 0.007(10) and 0.059(13) Å with the comparable metal atom displacement toward O(5) 0.072(1) and 0.077(1) Å for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. While those around Cu(2) are 0.261(12) Å and 0.093(12) Å with the metal atom displacement of 0.041(1) Å and 0.159(1) Å toward N(5). The Addison parameters for Cu(1) are 0.010 and 0.049 in complexes 1 and 2, respectively, and for Cu(2) in complex 2, it is 0.149, showing little distortions toward trigonal bipyramid geometry. The deviation from square planar geometry of Cu(2) in complex 1 is verified by calculating the τ4 index, which is 0.240 indicating a moderate distortion toward tetrahedral geometry.

elements.content: Unlike complexes 1 and 2, complex 3 is crystallized in the monoclinic system and C2/c space group (Table ). The molecular structure of complex 3 along with the atomic numbering scheme is shown in Figure . Two metalloligands [CuL] are chelated via bidentate μ2-phenoxido oxygen atom in a planar orientation. Along with it, three chelating nitrato (κ2O,O′) coligands are bound to the central TbIII atom building up a deca-coordination environment. The N,N′-bridging bpy molecule joins two successive (CuL)2Tb nodes via the axial site of the CuII centers of the coordinated metalloligands and propagates in an 1D zigzag manner along the crystallographic a axis. The molecule contains two C 2 axes passing parallel to the crystallographic b axis through the O(7)–N(5)–TbIII atoms and the middle of the bridging bpy molecule. It is noteworthy that the (CuL)2Tb(NO3)3 unit of this heterometallic 1D metal organic framework is similar to the structures reported earlier where the central metal atoms were CeIII, GdIII, and DyIII.

elements.content: The nature of coordination sphere of the central TbIII atom in complex 3 is quite different from those of complexes 1 and 2. In 1 and 2, the TbIII ion resides in an asymmetric nona-coordinated tricapped trigonal prism environment with a coordinated water. On the contrary, the vertexes of the coordination polyhedron of the central TbIII ion in complex 3 is symmetrically (C 2) constructed by 10 oxygen atoms from five bidentate ligands with an average Tb–O bond distance of 2.49(2) Å. Four oxygen atoms of the two metalloligands, i.e., O(1) and O(2) (and O(1b) and O(2b)) are at the distances of 2.389(6) and 2.368(7) Å (where the symmetry operation code of b is 1 – x, y, 1/2 – z), respectively. Four of them, i.e., O(3) and O(4) (and O(3b) and O(4b)) belong to two nitrato coligands at distances of 2.615(13) and 2.531(13) Å, respectively. The rest of them, i.e., O(6) (and O(6b)) belong to the symmetrically bidentate nitrate at a distance of 2.526(8) Å. The coordination polyhedron of the TbIII atom can be best described as a distorted tetradecahedron geometry. Six oxygen atoms, i.e., O(2), O(3), O(4), and O(2b), O(3b), O(4b) form nearly an equatorial plane, whereas O(1), O(1b), and O(6), O(6b) set of atoms organized at the opposite side of this plane in such a manner that the O(1)–Tb(1)–O(1b) plane bisects O(6) and O(6b). The r.m.s. deviations of the six equatorially coordinated atoms from the mean plane passing through them are 0.260(24) Å with the TbIII atom displaced toward O(1), O(1b) 0.095(1) Å. The distances of O(1) and O(6) from the mean equatorial plane are about 1.983 and 2.193 Å, respectively. The chelating angle to the TbIII center by the metalloligands lies at 63.7(2)°, whereas those of nitrato ligands are at 44.9(4)° and 50.2(3)° ().

elements.content: Each of the two symmetrically related terminal copper atoms of the trinuclear (CuIIL)2TbIII core in complex 3 is bonded to N2O2 donor set of atoms [O(1), O(2), N(1), N(2) for Cu(1)] of the tetradentate ligand L, making up the equatorial plane. The Cu–O and Cu–N distances are similar to those in 1 and 2. The axially coordinated nitrogen atom N(3) of the bridging bpy molecule is at a distance of 2.338(9) Å making a square-pyramidal geometry for Cu(1). The r.m.s. deviation of the four basally coordinated atoms from the mean plane passing through them is 0.021(17) Å with the metal atoms 0.200(1) Å for Cu(1) from this plane toward the axially coordinated N(3) atom of the bpy molecule. The Addison parameter of Cu(1) atom is 0.01, indicating a negligible amount of distortion toward trigonal bipyramid geometry.

elements.content: In summary, all three complexes comprise one crystallographically independent TbIII atom. The asymmetric TbO9 coordination polyhedrons in complexes 1 and 2 and the symmetric TbO10 in complex 3 share an edge with each of the two Cu coordination polyhedrons through doubly bridging μ1,1 phenoxido oxygen atoms with Cu–Tb distances in the range of 3.323(1)– 3.384(1) Å. The angles of the Cu–O–Tb bridges are in the range of 98.0(2)–102.8(2)° for all three complexes (Table ). The intramolecular Cu–Cu distance and Cu–Tb–Cu angle are 3.736(1) Å and 67.91(2)°, 3.972(2) Å and 72.23(2)°, and 6.242(4) Å and 135.8(1)° for complexes 1, 2, and 3, respectively, indicating a closer orientation of the metalloligands in the former two. The orientation of metalloligands in the (CuL)2Tb node is comparable with a butterfly where the TbIII lie at the body and two Cu–O2–Tb planes form its wings. The butterfly angles of the two Cu–O2–Tb planes are 49.7(1)° and 49.9(1)° for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, while that for 3 is 170.1(3) indicating a “bent” or “cisoid” form of (CuL)2Tb coordination cluster in 1 and 2 and nearly “linear” or “transoid” orientation in 3. The relative orientations of the bpy rings in the bpy ligand of 2 and 3 are quite different: they are planar in 2 but are twisted with a dihedral angle of 36.7(3)° in complex 3.

elements.content: All these complexes show a variety of supramolecular features (Table ). The contributions of both intra- and intermolecular hydrogen- (H−) bondings in complexes 1 and 2 have a crucial role in the molecular organization in the solid state. In both complexes, the axially coordinated nitrato coligand of the CuII center is stabilized by intramolecular H-bonding with the coordinated water molecule to the TbIII center. On the other hand, the intermolecular H-bonds between these coligands of the adjacent two molecules help to self-assemble the molecules parallel to the 01̅1 crystallographic plane either as a H-bonded dimer (for complex 1) or as a H-bonded 1D-zigzag chain (for complex 2). In addition, the H-bonded dimers in complex 1 are self-assembled to a 1D supramolecular column parallel to the 01̅1 plane by intermolecular C–H···O interaction at a H(22)···O(10)′ distance of 2.68(1) Å and ∠C–H···O′ angle of 147.7(6)° (the symmetry operation code of ′ is −x, 1 – y, 1 – z). The shortest (between the H-bonded dimer) distance between the terbium(III) centers along these supramolecular chains is 8.89(1) and 8.82(2) Å for complexes 1 and 2, respectively, indicating that the TbIII centers are well separated from each other. Compared to these two complexes, complex 3 demonstrates a rigid polymeric chain parallel to the a axis constructed by [(CuL)2Tb­(NO3)3bpy] building unit. The Cu(1b)···Cu(1)···Cu(1c) atoms lie at an angular disposition of 114.12(2)° that indicates a zigzag propagation of this heterometallic 1D metal–organic framework (MOF) (the symmetry operation code of c is 2 – x, y, 1/2 – z). No entanglement between the chains is found as observed for some other homometallic 1D MOFs. The TbIII centers along this chain are well separated by 15.37(1) Å. All complexes contain interstitial solvent molecules at the structural voids. In complex 1 in addition to a methanol solvate, a disordered water molecule is present with 50% occupancy at each site. On the other hand, complex 2 has two methanol solvates along with four closely assembled disordered water molecules, each with 50% occupancy at two sites. In complex 3, there are one methanol and two water solvates; all of them present in a disordered manner with 50% occupancy in the supramolecular channels formed.

It is to be noted that several well characterized 3d-4f complexes have been used as nodes to synthesize coordination polymers. Among them complexes of bicompartmental N2O4 donor ligands deserve a special mention as they can be joined easily by various linkers to obtain desired oligonuclear complexes and coordination polymers. The coordinative flexibility and versatility (changing of the Ln/M coordination number as well as the relative cis/trans-like mode of linking of the metal centers) of these nodes allow controlled aggregation. However, in such nodes, the O2O2′ compartment where the Ln resides is rather rigid without any significant conformational flexibility. In some other analogous 3d-4f nodes, the relative orientation of the 3d ions with respect to the Lns also seems to be fixed. Recently, we have shown that trinuclear conformationally flexible polymetallic (ML)2M′ nodes (around the O2M′O2′ coordination pocket) in a supramolecular architecture can offer unique structural diversities, e.g., isomers, pseudopolymorph, polymorphs, cocrystals, and supramolecular isomers. Gatteschi et al. in the mid-1980s synthesized trinuclear (CuL)2Ln (Ln = Eu, Gd) complexes in order to study the magnetic coupling between 3d-4f elements. Herein, we build its TbIII analogue (complex 1) and use it for the first time as a node to construct a dimer (2) and a 1D chain (3) by linking with bpy where the linker stoichiometry played a crucial role in metalloligand orientation around TbIII. In the case of the formation of the dimer where the linker stoichiometry is relatively low, the trinuclear node is folded to its “cisoid” (angular) form that produced an H-bonded pseudo 1D chain. On the other hand, when the linker stoichiometry is comparatively higher, the trinuclear node is unfolded to its “transoid” or nearly “linear” form to produce the 1D-zigzag chain. The stepwise assembling of polynuclear metallatectons had been done in a few cases utilizing nodes with coordinative flexibility or isomeric linker dicarboxylates with varying flexibility. However, the stoichiometric influence of a simple rigid di-imine spacer, bpy on coordination-driven self-assembly of a conformationally flexible heterometallic 3d-4f (ML)2M′ node and its utilization on stepwise supramolecular oligomerization have never been performed before. However, stoichiometric variation of this kind of linker had a distinct role in the growth of various homometallic MOFs and other molecular tectonics from discrete precursors.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibilities of polycrystalline 1–3 were measured at an applied magnetic field of 500 Oe. Figure shows the χm T vs T plots in a temperature range of 1.8–250 K. At room temperature, the χm T values of 1, 2, and 3 are 13.5, 26.3, and 12.5 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, which are close to that expected for two magnetically isolated Cu2+ ions (S = 1/2, g = 2) and one Tb3+ ion (J = 6, g J = 3/2) (12.6 cm3 K mol–1 for every (CuL)2Tb unit in theory). The χm T values are increased on cooling, suggesting the presence of ferromagnetic coupling between the Tb and Cu ions. A part of these increases would be attributed to a single-ion origin such as the Ising-type spin character remarkable in low temperatures. The final drops found below 5 K seem to be related with antiferromagnetic interaction ascribable to the coupling among the coordination cluster units (CuL)2Tb. No appreciable exchange coupling between the (CuL)2Tb units is operative in any compounds, because the final drop was practically negligible.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Magnetic susceptibilities of polycrystalline 1-3 were measured at an applied magnetic field of 500 Oe. Figure  shows the χm T vs T plots in a temperature range of 1.8-250 K. At room temperature, the χm T values of 1, 2, and 3 are 13.5, 26.3, and 12.5 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are close to that expected for two magnetically isolated Cu2+ ions (S = 1/2, g = 2) and one Tb3+ ion (J = 6, g  J  = 3/2) (12.6 cm3 K mol-1 for every (CuL)2Tb unit in theory). The χm T values are increased on cooling, suggesting the presence of ferromagnetic coupling between the Tb and Cu ions. A part of these increases would be attributed to a single-ion origin such as the Ising-type spin character remarkable in low temperatures. The final drops found below 5 K seem to be related with antiferromagnetic interaction ascribable to the coupling among the coordination cluster units (CuL)2Tb. No appreciable exchange coupling between the (CuL)2Tb units is operative in any compounds, because the final drop was practically negligible.

elements.content: The ferromagnetic couplings are eventually confirmed by the saturation magnetization. The magnetization curves of polycrystalline specimens of 1–3 were recorded at 1.8 K (the insets of Figure ). The rapidly saturated magnetization values are 11 μB and 22 μB for 1 and 2, respectively. These values clearly imply the presence of Tb–Cu ferromagnetic coupling with the ground J z = ± 6 for TbIII (11 μB for every ferromagnetic (CuL)2Tb unit in theory). Such ferromagnetic coupling is often observed in Gd–Cu and Tb–Cu heterometallic systems. The situation of 3 is somewhat different; the magnetization of 3 is nearly 9.5 μB per a repeating unit at 7 T, which is smaller than the theoretical 11 μB and still gradually increases even at 7 T. The observed slow saturation behavior can be explained in terms of the strong Tb magnetic anisotropy and the crystal structure of 3. The molecular arrangement in a space group monoclinic C2/c gives rise to a molecular magnetic easy axis arranged in a zigzag manner. Hence the bulk data is not a simple sum from the individual molecular values. Strong anisotropy seems to be responsible for SMM properties as well as spin-canted structures. On the other hand, 1 and 2 crystallize in a triclinic P1̅ space group, and the magnetic easy axis is unique in a crystal. No spin canting takes place.

elements.content: The ac magnetic susceptibilities of polycrystalline 1–3 were measured at 10–10000 Hz in a temperature range 1.9–20 K with and without an applied dc bias field of 1000 Oe. These complexes show no in-phase (χ′) and a very weak out-of-phase (χ″) signals under zero external field (, Figure S4). However, when a static field of 1000 Oe is applied, all the compounds show slow relaxation of magnetization (Figure ). With an increase of frequency, χ′ decrease and concomitant χ″ increase were shifted to a higher temperature. The frequency dependence of the χ″ peak temperature can be analyzed by the Arrhenius law. On the basis of the plots of the natural logarithm of the relaxation time τ is evaluated by 1/(2πν), where ν is the ac frequency, vs the inverse of the χ″ peak temperature T. The effective energy barrier of the magnetization reversal and pre-exponential factor τ0 were estimated to be U eff/k B = 20.3(7) K and τ0 = 1.5(4) × 10–7 s for 1, U eff/k B = 18.0(10) K and τ0 = 1.2(5) × 10–8 s for 2, and U eff/k B = 23.1(5) K and τ0 = 1.9(4) × 10–9 s for 3 (Figure ). These effective energy barriers are comparable with those of the known salen-based Cu–Tb heterometallic SMMs.

The effective energy barrier of the magnetization reversal and pre-exponential factor τ0 were estimated to be U eff/k B = 20.3(7) K and τ0 = 1.5(4) × 10-7 s for 1, U eff/k B = 18.0(10) K and τ0 = 1.2(5) × 10-8 s for 2, and U eff/k B = 23.1(5) K and τ0 = 1.9(4) × 10-9 s for 3 (Figure ). These effective energy barriers are comparable with those of the known salen-based Cu-Tb heterometallic SMMs.

elements.content: Figure shows a plot of χ″ against χ′ (the Cole–Cole plot) for 1–3. We applied the equation χ(ω) = χS + (χT – χS)/(1 + (iωτ)1−α)) where χT and χS are the isothermal and adiabatic susceptibilities, respectively. If one relaxation process is operative, the plot will display a semicircle with a small value of α. Actually these plots draw a partial semicircle, and the optimized α values were 0.347(10) at 1.9 K for 1, 0.408(12) and 0.388(12) at 1.9 and 2.0 K, respectively, for 2, and 0.37(2) and 0.41(4) at 1.9 and 2.0 K, respectively, for 3. The χ″ signals appeared in a narrow temperature range for 2 and 3, so that the experimental errors were relatively large for 2 and 3. Though comparably large α values were obtained, the present compounds can be concluded to be SMMs.

elements.content: Weakly interacted SMM systems attract much attention from the viewpoint of exchange-bias to improve the magnetic coercivity and some interesting quantum phenomena toward computing devices. From comparison of the SMM performance between 1 and 2, compound 1 showed larger U eff and longer τ0 than 2; namely, 1 is a potentially higher-T B SMM than 2. The axial coordination of bpy at each CuII ion in 2 is supposed to transmit negligible interaction. Thus, in the present study, the molecular design based on the exchange-biased SMMs was overridden by dominant single-ion properties. Both 1 and 2 possess only one crystallographically independent TbIII ion in a tricapped trigonal prism coordination sphere, but the latter has more inclined basal planes, possibly exerting the adverse effect on the magnetic anisotropy which largely depends on the strength and symmetry of the ligand field. Compound 3 exhibited a larger U eff and a smaller τ0 than those of 1 and 2. Again, the role of bpy as an exchange coupler seems to be limited here. The coordination structure and accordingly the crystal-field of the Tb ion in 3 are somewhat different from those of 1 and 2; the Tb in 3 is deca-coordinated, while those in 1 and 2 are nona-coordinated. In the present system the ligands on Tb3+ are allowed to be additionally coordinated and substituted with some other ligands. Such flexibility is crucial for the diversity of variously linked magnets but changes the single-ion properties as well to tune the SMM characteristics. To improve the magnetic coupling between the (CuL)2Tb unit, the coordination site of the nitrogen atoms from the bpy bridge would be better to be equatorial.

From comparison of the SMM performance between 1 and 2, compound 1 showed larger U eff and longer τ0 than 2; namely, 1 is a potentially higher-T B SMM than 2. The axial coordination of bpy at each CuII ion in 2 is supposed to transmit negligible interaction. Thus, in the present study, the molecular design based on the exchange-biased SMMs was overridden by dominant single-ion properties. Both 1 and 2 possess only one crystallographically independent TbIII ion in a tricapped trigonal prism coordination sphere, but the latter has more inclined basal planes, possibly exerting the adverse effect on the magnetic anisotropy which largely depends on the strength and symmetry of the ligand field. Compound 3 exhibited a larger U eff and a smaller τ0 than those of 1 and 2. Again, the role of bpy as an exchange coupler seems to be limited here. The coordination structure and accordingly the crystal-field of the Tb ion in 3 are somewhat different from those of 1 and 2; the Tb in 3 is deca-coordinated, while those in 1 and 2 are nona-coordinated. In the present system the ligands on Tb3+ are allowed to be additionally coordinated and substituted with some other ligands. elements.content: In order to assess the utility of “complex as a ligand” strategy for building 3d-4f SMM using N2O2 salen type Schiff base for the first time, a trinuclear Cu(II)–Tb(III) complex has been prepared using copper(II) complex of salpn as metalloligand. This complex is subsequently used as a polynuclear metallatecton, and in combination with bpy at different stoichiometry, it forms a dimer (H-bonded pseudo 1D chain) and a 1D-coordination polymer. The two metalloligands in the trinuclear node of these coordination-driven self-assemblies are cisoid in 1 and 2 but are transoid in 3. Such impact of stoichiometric variation of any di-imine linkers on the conformational flexibility of a polynuclear heterometallic node as well as the stepwise oligomerization is unprecedented in molecular tectonics. The present work reveals that the imine spacers in combination with the (ML)2M′ type nodes would be very useful for the future development of heterometallic complexes in crystal engineering and molecular tectonics. The Cu2Tb cores of these complexes show overall ferromagnetic exchange at low temperature through the phenoxido bridges. All three complexes exhibit slow relaxation of magnetization reorientation below 5 K, characteristic of SMMs or oligomeric aggregate of SMMs. However, we did not observe any significant positive modulation of magnetic anisotropy in the low symmetry environment of the nona-coordinated TbIII on dimerization of complex 1 to 2 or on polymerization of 1 to a more symmetrical deca-coordinated Tb in 3. Therefore, one needs to be cautious in exploring the oligo- or polymeric aggregates of SMM units which seems to be an attractive target in the present-day SMM research.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In order to assess the utility of "complex as a ligand" strategy for building 3d-4f SMM using N2O2 salen type Schiff base for the first time, a trinuclear Cu(II)-Tb(III) complex has been prepared using copper(II) complex of salpn as metalloligand. This complex is subsequently used as a polynuclear metallatecton, and in combination with bpy at different stoichiometry, it forms a dimer (H-bonded pseudo 1D chain) and a 1D-coordination polymer. The two metalloligands in the trinuclear node of these coordination-driven self-assemblies are cisoid in 1 and 2 but are transoid in 3. Such impact of stoichiometric variation of any di-imine linkers on the conformational flexibility of a polynuclear heterometallic node as well as the stepwise oligomerization is unprecedented in molecular tectonics. The present work reveals that the imine spacers in combination with the (ML)2M' type nodes would be very useful for the future development of heterometallic complexes in crystal engineering and molecular tectonics. The Cu2Tb cores of these complexes show overall ferromagnetic exchange at low temperature through the phenoxido bridges. All three complexes exhibit slow relaxation of magnetization reorientation below 5 K, characteristic of SMMs or oligomeric aggregate of SMMs. However, we did not observe any significant positive modulation of magnetic anisotropy in the low symmetry environment of the nona-coordinated TbIII on dimerization of complex 1 to 2 or on polymerization of 1 to a more symmetrical deca-coordinated Tb in 3. Therefore, one needs to be cautious in exploring the oligo- or polymeric aggregates of SMM units which seems to be an attractive target in the present-day SMM research.

Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.

Synthesis of the Schiff Base Ligand H<sub>2</sub>L and Ligand Complex [CuL]

The di-Schiff-base ligand H2L was prepared by a standard method. Five mmoles of 1,3- propanediamine (0.42 mL) was mixed with 10 mmol of salicylaldehyde (1.04 mL) in methanol (20 mL). The resulting solution was put under reflux for about 2 h and allowed to cool. The yellow-colored methanolic solution was used directly for complex formation. To a methanolic solution (20 mL) of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (1.852 g, 5 mmol), a methanolic solution of H2L (5 mmol, 10 mL) and triethyl amine (1.4 mL, 10 mmol) was added to prepare the respective precursor “metalloligand” [CuL] as reported earlier.

Synthesis of Complex [(CuL)<sub>2</sub>Tb(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>]­·MeOH­·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

The “metalloligand” [CuL] (343.5 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol and to it a solution of Tb(NO3)3·5H2O (217.5 mg, 0.5 mmol in 5 mL of methanol) was added and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The solution was filtered and kept for slow evaporation at room temperature. After 3 days, well-shaped dark green X-ray quality single crystals deposited at the bottom of the vessel. They were collected washed with a little methanol and allowed to dry at open atmosphere.

Synthesis of Complex [{(CuL)<sub>2</sub>Tb(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>}<sub>2</sub>bpy]­·2MeOH­·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

To a methanolic solution (5 mL) of complex 1 (350.0 mg, 0.32 mmol), a methanolic solution (2 mL) of 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy, 25.0 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added. After 3 days, block-shaped comparatively light green-colored single crystals deposited at the bottom of the vessel. Some of them were of X-ray quality. They were collected, washed with a little methanol, and allowed to dry at open atmosphere.

Yield: 66%, Anal. Calc. for C80H92Cu4N16O34Tb2 (2393.76): calcd. C 40.14, H 3.87, N 9.36; found. C 40.30, H 3.75, N 9.27; IR: ν(CN) = 1624 cm–1, ν(NO3 –) = 1560 cm–1 (ν1), 1281 cm–1 (ν2), 1036 cm–1 (ν3); UV/vis: λmax (MeOH, absorbance) = 602, 360, and 274 nm; λmax (solid, reflectance) = 617 and 374 nm.

Synthesis of Complex {[(CuL)<sub>2</sub>Tb(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>bpy]­·MeOH­·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex (3) was prepared by a similar method as described for complex 2. The only difference is that the proportion of 4,4′-bipyridine was doubled (bpy, 50.0 mg, 0.32 mmol) compared to that for 2. After 3 days, rhombic-shaped light green-colored single crystals were deposited at the bottom of the vessel. Some of them were X-ray quality. They were collected, washed with a little methanol, and allowed to dry at open atmosphere.

cln_elements.content: The ferromagnetic couplings are eventually confirmed by the saturation magnetization. The magnetization curves of polycrystalline specimens of 1–3 were recorded at 1.8 K (the insets of Figure ). The rapidly saturated magnetization values are 11 μB and 22 μB for 1 and 2, respectively. These values clearly imply the presence of Tb–Cu ferromagnetic coupling with the ground J z = ± 6 for TbIII (11 μB for every ferromagnetic (CuL)2Tb unit in theory). Such ferromagnetic coupling is often observed in Gd–Cu and Tb–Cu heterometallic systems. The situation of 3 is somewhat different; the magnetization of 3 is nearly 9.5 μB per a repeating unit at 7 T, which is smaller than the theoretical 11 μB and still gradually increases even at 7 T. The observed slow saturation behavior can be explained in terms of the strong Tb magnetic anisotropy and the crystal structure of 3. The molecular arrangement in a space group monoclinic C2/c gives rise to a molecular magnetic easy axis arranged in a zigzag manner. Hence the bulk data is not a simple sum from the individual molecular values. Strong anisotropy seems to be responsible for SMM properties as well as spin-canted structures. On the other hand, 1 and 2 crystallize in a triclinic P1̅ space group, and the magnetic easy axis is unique in a crystal. No spin canting takes place.
